title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization that has demonstrated effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training to healthcare providers in literacy promotion, delivering training curriculum in various medical education settings, offering technical assistance to healthcare facilities for implementing Pediatric Early Literacy Programs, providing discounted books to healthcare facilities, and integrating developmental research into training curriculum. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization that provides training to healthcare providers in literacy promotion and offers discounted books to healthcare facilities for implementing Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program encourages parents to read aloud to their children and offers strategies for early language and literacy promotion. The "Prescribe A Book Act" encourages parents to read aloud to young children, provides children's books to take home at health visits, and has volunteers read aloud to children in healthcare facilities. Research shows positive effects on parent behavior and language development in children. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes reading aloud to children, backed by research showing improved parent behavior and language development in young children. It also requires endorsement from national medical associations and academies. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application and provide matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. Grant funds must be used as specified. An eligible entity receiving a grant for a Pediatric Early Literacy Program must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies selected based on specific criteria. Contractors must prioritize serving at-risk children, particularly those from low-income families in high-poverty areas. The entity must provide training and technical assistance to contractors and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. The contractor must prioritize serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families, children without adequate medical insurance, children enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP programs, children in rural areas, migrant children, and children with limited library access. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities or their contractors have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts. Eligible entities receiving grants must report annually on program effectiveness. A conforming amendment is made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is amended to include a new subpart 22 for pediatric early literacy programs, outlining definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, payment restrictions, and reporting requirements. Eligible entities must have arrangements with book publishers for discounts and report annually on program effectiveness.
